process.title: My Process
process.subtitle: What separates me from other developers?
process.body: If you ask a developer what they use to make a website, one might say Dreamweaver, another might say Wordpress and another might say Vim or Node. Just this one answer can tell you tons about the nature of those developers. While it doesn't necessarily provide a way to know which one might be more skilled at software architecture, it does tell you which one probably has more knowledge that reaches beyond the average script-kiddies.
process.asside: I have talked to many developers who say they know JavaScript, when in fact what they really know is how to modify jQuery code. What I do here is outline the general approach and tools I use for interactive project construction. This should give you a good idea as to the type of developer I am.

point.headline: JavaScript
point.body: Most developers are going to say they know JavaScript but since JavaScript is a separate art in it's own right, I encourage prospective clients to really understand the level that someone knows JavaScript. I don't simply modify JavaScript libraries or use a DOM manipulation tool like JQuery. I write custom JavaScript that follows the MVC design pattern utilizing tools like Angular , Backbone, RequireJS, Node and Jade. When I say I know JavaScript, I really know it.

point.headline: CSS
point.body: Again, all developers are going to say they know CSS but how many understand why and when to use an icon-font, manage high-density displays, integrate view transitions, handle gestures in the presentation layer or manage complex z-index states? I do.

point.headline: Build Process
point.body: Web applications have grown to a complexity level that they now require more robust techniques for deployment, performance optimization and overall organization. The industry-standard tools for doing this is Grunt or Gulp , and I love to find ever-efficient ways to use it for tasks like image compression, code compilation, linting, minifying and running automated acceptance tests.

point.headline: Version Control
point.body: There are only benefits to using Git so any developer that doesn't, usually hasn't worked in teams. I understand feature branches, rebases, resolving merge conflicts, hooks, and even reflog. I love Git deployment but if I am stuck dealing with FTP, I'll use something like Dandelion. If Rsync is at least an option, I'll use grunt-rsync so I can automate deployment as part of my build process .

point.headline: Pre-compilers
point.body: Every developer is going to say they know CSS. What this really means, is that they understand how to position and style DOM elements. I take this further with Sass and the Compass framework to organize, optimize and generate cross-device/browser code. I also use custom Sass mixins to further organize mobile-first styles. Many developers don't consider things like Webclips when coding. I do. What this means for a client, is simply that I create more organized code with faster load times.

point.headline: REST
point.body: Today's applications don't just consume data from 3rd party sources, but also need to supply data; even if it's to its own user interface. I follow strict REST principles so when another developer takes over my work, he/she should be able to easily understand how the application works.

point.headline: Community
point.body: I love the developer community. I provide quite a few tutorials for other developers on my YouTube channel with my tutorial on Git being especially popular.

point.headline: Browser testing
point.body: Today's interactive applications must run on many platforms. The average project I do is tested in over 30 browser versions. I personally own most software platforms and test locally including Microsoft's Surface Pro, Android, iOS, and can emulate all desktop browsers.

point.headline: Testing
point.body: Unit, functional and acceptance testing is the practice of writing code that checks parts of the application for errors. This practice usually results in more stable code with less bugs. When I write tests, I usually use Codeception or Jasmine.

process.close: As you can see, there are many aspects to creating the rich interactive experiences that people expect. Using the right tools and techniques means development will cost less, the app will be easier to maintain and is generally less prone to fail. As a prospective client, you'll need to decide if these things are valuable to your next project.
